entry.summary: The email discusses a proposal called bip118, which allows for a pubkey of "1" to represent the taproot inner pubkey. Adding an opcode like OP_INNER_PUBKEY is suggested as an alternative approach. The email also addresses taproot malleability bugs and provides a link for further discussion on this topic.Another email in the thread presents a proposal that combines bip118 and bip119, aiming to retain the low risk associated with each proposal. This proposal clarifies the similarities and differences between bip118 and bip119. It introduces three new Tapscript-only opcodes and explains their behavior. The motivation behind the proposal is to address objections raised against bip119 and bip118 and provide upgrade paths.The email provides technical details about the proposed opcodes, including their behavior during validation. It compares the efficiency of the proposal to bip118 and bip119 in different scenarios. It also discusses the use of the proposal in ln-symmetry, PTLCs, and OP_VAULT. Additionally, it explains what fields are hashed in different modes.Overall, the email provides a detailed description of a proposal combining bip118 and bip119, highlighting its advantages and addressing concerns raised against the individual proposals.The author, Brandon, advises against using techniques like `OP_CHECKSIG(VERIFY)` or creating infinite hash loops in programming, as they can be dangerous. He stresses the need for a formal and informative tone while summarizing the main points of the email. Proper spacing after punctuation and adherence to grammatical rules are emphasized. Retaining and utilizing any provided links correctly is important. The farewell part of the email should be ignored. The extracted summary should restructure and simplify the main points, rather than simply rephrasing the original content. The length of the summary may vary depending on the size of the email.
